The salary offered is significantly high for a candidate from Tier 1 college. For example: A fresher having an IIT/NIT tag will be offered a minimum of 16 LPA+ and PL10 level. Compare that to a person from a non premier college with 3 years of experience will only be offered 10 to 12 LPA.So what I am trying to say is scale of salary over here is different depending on the college you studied in.In general salary growth over here is around 15 - 20% every year on average, atleast in DH, with occasional correction of about 30-35% every few years.Overall there is good WLB, but at times it gets messed up due to the acute talent shortage (but still better than a lot of companies). For the first time I have seen a lot of genuinely good people at one place compared to the previous companies I have worked in.Anyways good luck in the salary negotiation. If you really feel HR might be willing to give more, then please feel free to negotiate. Atleast try to negotiate some other components like the joining bonus or the retention bonuses.PS: A lot of people still get half the tc with 10+ years of experience within the company  :p

Mentor Graphics has technical levels  from T06 (starting level Engineer) to T12 which is equivalent to Fellow or VP of engineering. Base + bonus at T10 can range from $160k - $230k depending on your location and years of experience. A lot of folks at T10 and below have PhDs and you need a lot of research papers business impact to grow any further. Some years of you do well, there is discretionary stock grants as well.
C-E or D-E 40, TC: 110-140k range depending on location. DE 40 is lead and CE 40 or BE 40 is entry level

Just make sure you negotiate like hell coming in. Annual pay raises rarely even hit 2%. Target bonus at CE and DE are both 10% and rarely would exceed 13-14% since the internal guidelines strongly limit manager discretion even if you got 150% of your personal targets and the company hit its numbers.

To be hired as a research scientist like that you need solid credentials. You don’t have that. Research papers are cheap, thousands phd every year, doing useless research. To get attention to the tech world, you need a bit more than that.

Ok first.. A lot of research scientists are actually doing applied research and engineering with a fancier title.Do you want both research freedom and money? Then you should be extremely good at your job to get hired by Google Brain, FAIR, Deepmind, or Open AI. The list is short because it is a ridiculously privileged position. If you don’t see a path to get hired by those companies, the truth might be that there’s no path.
You are right. The truth is not pleasant.

It would not hurt to do more research about the roles in these companies, and look for a role that fits you instead of a fancy title. For example, at FB any PhD grad ML engineer can get the RS title, but they are still more of a ML engineer unless you are in FAIR. At G, most RS are expected to code heavily, oftentimes in C++. At Amazon, it is widely known that applied scientist is the most prestigious and highest paid job family, and they engage the research community just as much as their RS.

Easiest way to become a research scientist is to get your professor hired and your lab acquired. Other than that, it's really hard since there aren't many true research positions. Some companies like FB call all PhDs research scientists even if they do no research.
